sub_title: Developer and lead of collaborative research projects for Green Cities and urban regions . PhD
summary:
Developing knowledge for better governing green open space in urban regions worldwide. This demands a combination of strong government with multi-stakeholder cooperations; spatial visions for urban regions that integrate knowledge from natural and social sciences, the 3 Ps. As researcher with a background in both domains (society-nature interface) I want to support the sustainable urbanization, taking care of humans and nature. 
I like working with practitioners because they are getting things done. 
In 2019 I concluded my PhD in Copenhagen on 'Governing and transition of greenspace in urban regions', linked to my work at Wageningen Environmental Research.  I am developing projects that aim for transition in greenspace. One of those projects is The New Gardener. Gardening companies get a more important role in integrated greenspace management, as intermediaries between residents and commissioners like municipalities, housing corporations and waterboards. Another project is the study of personal transport innovations, like beemcars. These may have a huge potential for reducing the urban rural dichotomy, improving quality of life and climate adaptation and mitigation. It might create new economies. This requires substantial research together with travellers associations, transport companies and urban and regional authorities. 'transdisciplinary socio-technical-environmental system research'.

Het vraagt aandacht voor het tegengaan van de tweedeling tussen steden en landelijke gebieden.

projects.title: De Nieuwe Hovenier / the New Gardener
projects.description: The project develops demonstration projects with Dutch landscape contractors. They take a bigger role in managing urban greenspace in a more integrated manner, connecting with the various partners, including local residents. Lessons from theory and practice are turned into films and text for the new generation of landscape contractors and other green sector students. Main issues such as climate adaptation, health, social cohesion, employment and biodiversity are included.

projects.title: Initiative in Nature and management. Between authorities, citizens and parkmanagers
projects.description: As project leader of this project (70.000 euros, Ministry of Economic Affairs) I am responsible for the development of training materials for students, including weblectures, films of on-site actions of citizens and social companies and of interviews with the actors involved. E.g. citizen initiators, local officers, alderman, water board officer, state forestry officer. eg. in Rotterdam, a remote area in Groningen and a village in the province Overijssel. Together with colleague experts we provide lectures on citizens initiatives in urban and rural areas and themes like dilemmas for officers, how to support the initiatives, jurisdictional dimensions, and the internal dynamic of citizens initiatives.

projects.title: PLUREL Peri-urban land use relations and governance and spatial planning strategies EU FP6
projects.description:
In this four years research project we worked together with regional authorities from Greater Manchester, Montpellier Agglomeration, Leipzig-Halle region, The Hague Region, Warsaw Mazovian Region, Koper region, Hangzhou (China). I coordinated the governance and case study research (2.4 million euros) and organized the interaction between researchers and practitioners. Practitioners brought in their own research questions and criteria for sustainability assessment. The researchers from the seven countries included these in their research on governance and spatial planning strategies. A feedback in terms of recommendations was delivered, also based on scenario development for the regions and integrated assessments. I worked on the international comparison together with Katarina Eckerberg from (then) SEI and Umea University in Sweden. We developed recommendations. see articles. 
I initiated this project in follow up to the Greencluster project which Alterra coordinated. Kjell Nilsson from (then) Copenhagen University was project coordinator of the whole PLUREL project. Some 40 research organizations and enterprises were involved.

projects.title: Amsterdam Osdorp
projects.description:
This small but effective project (20.000 euros) was about park design through a cooperative proces with some eight social groups of different background. Indigenous and immigrant groups and youth were involved. Following an approach using 'tools for transition' . Contributing to communication and cohesion between the groups and a shared vision on the desired plan as a meeting place for all. Financed by two housing corporations, local authority and developers. I worked on this project with Anne Haars, from the Support Point for Housing, a residence organization.This kind of work is so incredibly positive that even at eleven in the evening we were still full of energy and entusiasm.
Similar projects were about working with children or youth to discuss their ideas for green open space, by means of drawings, taking photographs, putting flags at ugly or beautifull places, etc.

projects.title: GREENCLUSTER project EU FP4 Accomupanying measure
projects.description: The two years project Greencluster exchanged and integrated the knowledge that was developed by five EU research projects on urban green open space. Some 25 European research institutes and many more cities were involved. 3D modelling, insights on cooperative management of green open space, benefits of green open space, etc. The involved EU projects were GREENSCOM, BUGS, GREENSPACE, URGE and RUROS. I wrote the proposal for this project together with Leo van den Berg and was in charge of the strategic aspects of the coordination of Greencluster project. Together with Sandra Wohlleber  from - then - UFZ I wrote the paper on Tools for decisionmaking on urban green space in Europe.

projects.title: Greenscom Communicating Urban Growth and Green EU FP4
projects.description:
Greenscom was a 3 years research project on the role and workings of communication between different interest groups in a context of urban growth. Communication between urban planners and citizens, but also between researchers and practitioners was studied. Together with Chalmers University, FORS recherche sociale, Helsinki Technical University and Danish Building (then By-og-byg) we did six case studies: Cergy Pontoise, Utrecht-Houten, Gothenburg, Helsinki, Tampere, Aarhus.
Central issues were the communicative approach, Tools for Transition versus tools in action and tools for interaction. Especially the tools for transition have my interest. Throughout my carreer I have learned to see the differences in communicative values of different tools. See also the Contractual Approach at ILO. Our involvement in this project (1.5 million euros) was funded by the EC (FP5 Cultural Heritage and Cities of Tomorrow) and the Dutch Ministry of Housing, and the Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality. I coordinated the project.

projects.title: Assessment Instrument for Transport Innovation
projects.description: Urban greenspace is under pressure and innovative modes of transport like beemcar, skytran, could have benefits we are not yet aware of. What factors are relevant when comparing modes of transport? And how could a local street in Beatrixquarter or the 10 minutes ring in Utrecht look like? Ineke Weppelman (3D), Michiel van Eupen (2D) and Carmen Aalbers (list of factors) find that we should investigate the different new transport options that could support a more healthy urban environment. Costs might also be a competitive advantage of these new modes.
